lead_paragraph: Nigeria’s new president has focused on eliminating corruption in the military and, although doubts remain, the U.S. is ready to sell 12 warplanes to Nigeria.

byline.contributor: Helene Cooper reported from Arusha, and Dionne Searcy from Dakar, Senegal.
byline.original: By HELENE COOPER and DIONNE SEARCEY

headline.print_headline: Push to Sell Planes Shows U.S. Thaw With Nigeria
headline.main: After Years of Distrust, U.S. Military Reconciles With Nigeria to Fight Boko Haram

snippet: Nigeria’s new president has focused on eliminating corruption in the military and, although doubts remain, the U.S. is ready to sell 12 warplanes to Nigeria.
abstract: Obama administration says it is prepared to sell up to 12 light attack aircraft to Nigeria to help in country's fight against militant group Boko Haram; move, coming two years after administration blocked sale of attack helicopters to Nigeria due to human rights concerns, points to warming military relations between countries; rights groups have criticized pending sale, saying Pres Muhammadu Buhari has not done enough to stop abuse and corruption.

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
